utterances: A lot of us would.

I'm a 31-year-old woman.
I was named Darth nearly two years before the first Star Wars movie came out, although, I was tortured in elementary school for my name.
As an adult, I've come to appreciate it.
It seems to be a good icebreaker.
And people seldom forget my name as they might just another Jennifer.
We're talking about unusual names this hour, and the burden we're all forced to carry.
E-mail is talk@npr.org.
I'm Neal Conan.
We'll be back after the break.
It's TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
We're talking about people who at some point in their lives could not stand their own names, means most of us probably.
There's now another concern for parent's - Google.
An article in the Wall Street Journal explains that parents want their kids to be searchable online.
Name the new baby John Smith and he'll be buried in millions of results.
But Colder Wilson(ph) might show up at the top of the page, which might give him an advantage later in life or so the argument goes.
And the thing is, it's good and bad because when you see my name it's usually - it's me, it is me.
It's you.
And, so you have to - it's actually either good or bad.
You can read more about that online.
There's a link to the article on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.
Do you hate your name or maybe struggle to find a unique name for your kids, one that won't get them beaten up on the playground.

And you can send us your stories on our blog.

And here's a comment from Susan(ph) on our blog.
When I was growing up I knew a Copper Penny(ph), a Hollywood(ph) and a Rocky Beach(ph).
My last name was the subject of some ridicule Tank(ph).
My brother, who was somewhat large, was called Sherman by his friends.
Here's another comment from our blog.
My name Talus(ph) pronounced with a flat A and a schwa U - and I think I got that right - gets many questions.
It can mean two things, an anklebone or crumbled boulders on a steep hill.
I like to thank the latter applies to me in school.
Whenever there was a substitute teacher, oh boy, it is never pronounced correctly.
Kathy(ph) in Charlotte, North Carolina, what's in a name?
Usually, not much, she says, unless prospective interviewers can tell you're black from reading yours on a resume.
I wonder how many more interviews I would have gotten had my dad gotten his wish to name me Helga after an early - elderly German woman who befriended him when he was in the service.
I name my own child an African name, it looks similar to a newly common white name only it's pronounced differently.
This way, she gets the best of both worlds.
We honor our heritage and she can pass the initial resume review.

Joining us now is Gayman Wong(ph).
She works in Capital and Finance in the Division of Budgets for Caltrans in Sacramento, California.
She joins us today from the studios of member station KXJC in Sacramento.
Nice to have you on the program today.
Hi, Neal.
How are you?
Gayman Wong.
I'm very well, thanks.
Gayman Wong, though, this, say, you again have the double whammy.
Yes, I do.
First, let's go with the first name.
Gayman.
Does people see that's spelled out G-A-Y-M-A-N?
And I assume hilarity ensues.
Yes.
I've - all my life, I've had people ask me about my name almost every single day of my life.
And it is a great icebreaker by the way.
It is a great icebreaker.
But, where does it in fact come from?
Well, when I was born my mother wanted to name me Renee, and my father hated that name, so she said, well, I think I'll name her Gayman.
And I think, she says that she chose that name because she was reading French novels at that time, and I think she thought it sounded French, and I was born on Bastille Day.
Ah, and gamin is a waif of the streets.
Waif of the streets.
Yeah, I look like a little waif when I was born.
Aha.
And so, she changed the spelling, and so now my name is uniquely my own.
All right.
Enough of a burden, and then you marry a name - a man named Wong.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Yes.
My maiden name is Miller, and having the name Gayman Miller was enough trouble on the playground.
But as an adult, I married my husband and now my name is Gayman Wong, and that causes new problems.
Because you're not a man.
I am…
And you're not Chinese.
No.
I - when people see my name, they assume that I'm a man and that I'm Chinese.
And so, when I go for a job interview, or if I go somewhere for - to talk and people don't know who I am or what I look like, when they see me, they're bowled over.
(Soundbite of laughter)
They're really surprised.
Really surprised.
Because - you should describe yourself.
Well, I' blonde-haired, blue-eyed, and I don't look Chinese, and I'm female.
So, it just shocks them when they see me.
I'm sure you've had the experience that of, you know, they're looking straight at you and they look around, Gayman Wong?
Gayman Wong?
Right.
That's…
Yeah.
…absolutely.
And that happens all the time.
And I do have people look at me for a long time and then they'll say, is your husband Chinese?
They'll finally figure it out.
And I'll say - sometimes I say no.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Just to mess with their heads.
Just to mess with their heads, and then I'll say, yeah, he is.
It's been an interesting life, I suspect.
It has.
It has.
When I was little, the kids did make fun of me.
They really never twisted my name around.
They would just make fun of the name.

They wouldn't say Gayman - Gayman Hayman or anything like that, they would just, you know, you have to remember, I was born at a time when most little girls were named Cathy, Sheryl, Debbie, Susie, and then here comes Gayman.
So, you can imagine.
I don't think it's terribly popular even now.
